text:
Growing up in a pretty
homogeneous society

as a woman working in a
male dominated environment,

I could not help but see
that I was different.

And I could not help but
see that in this society,

diversity was not always
seen as a positive element.

And so my passion to pursue
diversity and inclusion

and to promote in the workplace
really stems from this.
I'm from Milan, Italy.

Prior to HBS, I worked
in management consulting.

After a few years in
the job, I kind of
realized that I could do more.

My job was great, but at the
same time, as I looked around

and I saw all these
companies really lacking

competitive advantage
because of their workforce,

and I realized that
I really wanted
to turn this into my career.

It's not just an
ethical imperative.

It's a business one,
because a society that

doesn't include people
who are different

is a society that is not bound
to succeed in the long term.

I made a lot of excuses
not to apply to HBS

and convincing myself that
I was not the right person.
My resume is not strong enough.

I have no time to
craft my application.

I did not study at
an Ivy League school.
My English is not perfect.
I'm an introvert.

And with so many people applying
to Harvard every year, why me?

The application process
was a transformation
before the transformation.

It really helped me reach
clarity around my goals.

It helped me transform my
intent into a clear path forward

and my dreaming into something
that I could almost touch.

The people closest to
me really convinced
me to apply to HBS ultimately.

They kind of made me
realize that I was only

focusing on the negative
parts, and I was creating
excuses for me not to apply.

And that instead, I
should focus on what it
is that I bring to the table.

What is the value that I can
add to the HBS community?

Applying to HBS really
had a ripple effect.

I had to overcome my
fear of raising my hand.

I had to really defend my own
ideas in front of a classroom.
And that was really empowering.

And then gave me the confidence
to run as WSA co-president.

The Women's Student Association
is the largest student club
on campus.

And it really
caters to all women.

And its mission is to make
sure that all women can thrive

personally, professionally,
academically,
and socially at HBS and beyond.

Now that I'm almost at the
end of my journey at HBS

and if I look back
at the old Erica,

I definitely see a
different person.

HBS is not just a career switch
or a different job opportunity.

It's a journey to become
the kind of leader who

affects community, who
brings about change.

And that's a person
who I wanted to become.
